title: L'amor coniugale
text:
L'amor coniugale (Conjugal Love) is an <a href="opera">opera</a> in one act by <a href="Simon%20Mayr">Simon Mayr</a> set to an Italian <a href="libretto">libretto</a> by <a href="Gaetano%20Rossi">Gaetano Rossi</a>. It premiered at Padua's <a href="Teatro%20Verdi%20%28Padova%29">Teatro Nuovo</a> on 26 July 1805.
Background and performance history.
Like Beethoven's "<a href="Fidelio">Fidelio</a>", the libretto of "L'amor coniugale" is based on <a href="Jean-Nicolas%20Bouilly">Jean-Nicolas Bouilly</a>'s French libretto for <a href="Pierre%20Gaveaux">Pierre Gaveaux</a>'s 1798 opera "<a href="L%C3%A9onore%2C%20ou%20l%27amour%20conjugal">Léonore, ou l'amour conjugal</a>". Unlike "Fidelio" which focuses on the struggle for political liberty, Mayr's opera, also known as "Il custode di buon cuore" (The Good-hearted Jailer) and described in its libretto as a "farsa sentimentale", focuses more on the interpersonal relationships between the protagonists and contains comic elements. Rossi condensed Bouilly's two-act libretto into one act containing 19 scenes and changed the setting from the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> to 17th century Poland.
"L'amor coniugale" premiered at the Teatro Nuovo in Padua on 26 July 1805 in a double bill with the premiere of "La donna di spirito". It was then performed the following September at the <a href="Teatro%20San%20Benedetto">Teatro San Benedetto</a> in Venice. Although rarely performed now, it was revived at the <a href="Teatro%20Donizetti">Teatro Donizetti</a> in Bergamo in November 1984 conducted by <a href="Bruno%20Moretti">Bruno Moretti</a> and in Germany at the 2004 <a href="Rossini%20in%20Wildbad">Rossini in Wildbad</a> Festival conducted by Christopher Franklin. The Wildbad performance used a revised score by Arrigo Gazzaniga and was issued by the <a href="Naxos%20Records">Naxos Records</a> label.
